pullRequest.body:
This constructs a group isomorphism `unitary (H ‚ÜíL[ùïú] H) ‚âÉ‚ãÜ (H ‚âÉ‚Çó·µ¢[ùïú] H)` where `H` is a Hilbert space. In addition, several lemmas are provided for convenience concerning unitary operators.

---

- [x] depends on: #10855

nodes.body:
This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10855~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

@JonBannon Thanks for the review! I would recommend asking this sort of question on Zulip, if only to make sure they get some visibility. I'll still answer it though :-) It might feel a bit counterintuitive, but checking the proofs is not the main priority when reviewing -- we already know they are correct, and stylistic issues inside proofs are a minor issue since they have no impact on the rest of the library. We are much more interested in checking whether statements can be used easily later, if lemmas have the right names, if they're in the right file, if the defs are the best ones, or at the right level of generality, if the documentation is good, etc.

Thanks!

> library. We are much more interested in checking whether statements can be
> used easily later, if lemmas have the right names, if they're in the right
> file, if the defs are the best ones, or at the right level of generality,

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8190911684/job/22398939259)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8190911684/job/22398938763)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8190911684/job/22398938500)

Unfortunately, this is my first review, and so it will be essentially LGTM, since I'm more or less happy at this stage to have a vague understanding of what each thing is doing...but I could not generate this proof myself! For future reference, is it best to, when reviewing these, try to write a more extensive tactic proof and then try to understand how to pare it back to something like this? 

Is a review like this a good place to raise discussion points about what each bit does, or is that not the done thing?
Looks good, thanks!

Unfortunately, this is my first review, and so it will be essentially LGTM, since I'm more or less happy at this stage to have a vague understanding of what each thing is doing...but I could not generate this proof myself! For future reference, is it best to, when reviewing these, try to write a more extensive tactic proof and then try to understand how to pare it back to something like this? 

Is a review like this a good place to raise discussion points about what each bit does, or is that not the done thing?
Looks good, thanks!

```suggestion
/-- The unitary elements of continuous linear maps on a Hilbert space coincide with the linear
isometric equivalences on that Hilbert space. -/
```
This seems doubly misnamed: it doesn't involve `unitary` nor `linearIsometryEquiv`. How about something like `LinearIsometryEquiv.star_eq_symm`?
Oops, that's because it used to!
Done, and I added a version for `adjoint`.
Could you use `adjoint` in the theorem name, to match the statement?
ditto
Make u implicit?
Make u implicit?

```suggestion
theorem norm_map (u : unitary (H ‚ÜíL[ùïú] H)) (x : H) : ‚Äñ(u : H ‚ÜíL[ùïú] H) x‚Äñ = ‚Äñx‚Äñ :=
```
I think we prefer the coercion over the explicit `.val` (although in the end they are the same thing). Same thing several times below.
I'm not entirely sure how I feel about this as a prescriptive statement, but I've implemented it nevertheless.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: unitary operators on a Hilbert space coincide with linear isometric equivalences
